questions.text: What is the most common cause of cell injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hypoxia

Explanation:

  • Hypoxia is the most common cause of cell injury.
  • The mechanism of hypoxic cell injury is a decrease in oxygen concentration at the tissue level.
  • The most common cause of hypoxia is ischemia.
  • Ischemia is the hampered blood supply.

questions.text: Identify the correct combination of most and least sensitive cells to hypoxia.

choices.text: Most sensitive - hepatocytes and least sensitive - Lymphocytes
Most sensitive - bone marrow cells and least sensitive - nerve cells
Most sensitive - retina and least sensitive - adipose tissue
Most sensitive - neurons and least sensitive - fibroblasts

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Most sensitive - neurons and least sensitive - fibroblasts

Explanation:

The cells most sensitive to hypoxia are neurons and the least sensitive are fibroblasts.

  • Neurons or Brain cells: Features of cell injury can be seen after 3 to 5 minutes of hypoxia.
  • Fibroblasts: Hypoxia can be tolerated for more than 60 minutes.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a feature of reversible cell injury?

choices.text: Large amorphous densities in the mitochondria
Detachment of ribosomes from granular ER

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Large amorphous densities in the mitochondria.

Explanation:

Large amorphous densities are seen in the mitochondria in irreversible cell injury.

  • Amorphous densities in the mitochondria mean calcium deposition in mitochondria, which occurs when the cell membrane has been ruptured.
  • The following changes occur in reversible cell injury:
    • Cellular swelling: Earliest change
      • Na and water accumulate within the cell, causing cellular swelling (swelling of the endoplasmic reticulum) (Option C ruled out)
    • ATP depletion leads to sodium-potassium pump failure (Option B ruled out)
    • Due to ATP dysfunction, ribosomes detach from the endoplasmic reticulum, which stops protein synthesis (Option D ruled out)

questions.text:
Match the following descriptions of the nuclear changes in irreversible cell injury.


	
		
			
			       I. Pyknosis
			
			
			 a. Nuclear fragmentation
			
		
		
			
			      II. Karyorrhexis
			
			
			 b. Dissolution of nucleus
			
		
		
			
			      III. Karyolysis
			
			
			 c. Shrinking of the nucleus and clumping of nuclear chromatin
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) I-c, II-a, III-b

Explanation:

The nuclear changes seen in irreversible cell injury are as follows:

Pyknosis

Shrinking of the nucleus and clumping of nuclear chromatin

Karyorrhexis

Nuclear fragmentation

Karyolysis

Dissolution of the nucleus
Order of the Events: P - K - K: Pyknosis - Karyorrhexis - Karyolysis

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important electron microscopic finding in irreversible cell injury?

choices.text: Small amorphous densities in the mitochondria
Large amorphous densities in the mitochondria
Detachment of ribosomes from the granular endoplasmic reticulum

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Large amorphous densities in the mitochondria

Explanation:

Large amorphous densities in the mitochondria are the most important electron microscopic finding in irreversible cell injury. It occurs due to an increased calcium influx in the mitochondria. 

Irreversible cell injury:

 

  • Severe membrane damage leading to influx of calcium.
  • Severe mitochondrial damage leads to the formation of large, flocculant, amorphous densities due to increased calcium influx.

Reversible cell injury: 

  • Small amorphous densities in the mitochondria
  • Swelling of the endoplasmic reticulum
  • Detachment of ribosomes from the granular endoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding free radical injury is true?

choices.text: Free radicals are highly stable molecules with unpaired electrons that contribute positively to cellular functions.
Free radical injury can lead to cell damage through lipid peroxidation, protein oxidation, and DNA strand breaks.
Antioxidants play a minor role in protecting cells from free radical damage.
Free radicals primarily cause cell death through apoptosis and do not contribute to necrosis.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Free radical injury can lead to cell damage through lipid peroxidation, protein oxidation, and DNA strand breaks.

Explanation:

Free radical injury can indeed lead to cell damage through processes such as lipid peroxidation (which damages cell membranes), protein oxidation (which affects enzyme function and structural integrity), and DNA strand breaks (which can lead to mutations).

  • Free radicals are highly stable with unpaired electrons that contribute negatively to cellular functions. (Option A ruled out)
  • Antioxidants play a major role in protecting cells from free radical damage; therefore, the diet should be rich in antioxidants, such as vitamins A, C, and E. (Option C ruled out)
  • Free radicals cause cell death through apoptosis and also contribute to necrosis. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A sample of tissue preparation is subjected to oxidative stress under experimental conditions. Different types of free radicals are generated in the process. However, the researcher wants to work on the most potent and reactive free radicals among the ones generated. Which of the following will he be working on?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Hydroxyl radical.

Explanation:

When a tissue sample is exposed to oxidative stress experimentally, various free radicals are produced, with the hydroxyl radical being the most potent and reactive among them.

  • We have a total of 3 free radicals: 
    • Superoxide
    • Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2)
    • Hydroxyl (OH)
  • The hydroxyl radical (OH•) is considered the most potent and reactive free radical due to its high reactivity and ability to quickly react with cellular components, leading to oxidative damage.
  • Hydroxyl radicals are primarily formed through the Fenton reaction
    • The interaction of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) with transition metal ions such as iron (Fe) or copper (Cu).

questions.text: Which of the following is a telltale sign of free radical injury in cells?

choices.text: Increased antioxidant levels in the cell
Generation of Lipofuscin and stress markers such as malondialdehyde (MDA)

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Generation of Lipofuscin and stress markers such as malondialdehyde (MDA).

Explanation:

The presence of lipofuscin and stress markers like malondialdehyde (MDA) is a telltale sign of free radical-induced cellular injury.

  • Free radical injury results in oxidative stress (Lipid peroxidation), leading to the accumulation of oxidative stress markers such as malondialdehyde (MDA) and the generation of Lipofuscin.
  • Lipofuscin is positive for Oil Red-O stain.
  • These are the tell-tale signs of free radical injury.

questions.text: What is the primary function of superoxide dismutase (SOD) in cells?

choices.text: Neutralization of superoxide anion radicals (O2•-) into hydrogen peroxide (H2O2)

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Neutralization of superoxide anion radicals (O2•-) into hydrogen peroxide (H2O2)

Explanation:

Neutralization of superoxide anion radicals (O2•-) into hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is the primary function of Superoxide Dismutase (SOD) in cells.

  • Dual functions of Superoxide dismutase (SOD):
    1. Generation of free radicals by converting superoxide into H2O2 
    2. Neutralization (Primary function) (Option C)
  • Its primary function is to catalyze the conversion of superoxide radicals (O2•-) into oxygen (O2) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2).
  • The only antioxidant that can break free radicals in the brain is Superoxide dismutase.
  • SOD1 gene mutation in humans is associated with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS).

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with progressive weakness and muscle atrophy, primarily affecting his arms and legs. He reports difficulty with tasks such as buttoning shirts and lifting objects. On examination, you note fasciculations in his upper extremities and decreased muscle strength. His reflexes are brisk, and there is no sensory deficit. Nerve conduction studies show signs of denervation. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the SOD1 gene. Based on this clinical scenario, what is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)

Explanation

This clinical scenario, marked by progressive limb weakness, muscle atrophy with fasciculations, brisk reflexes, denervation on nerve studies, and an SOD1 gene mutation, is diagnostic of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS).

  • It is a disease of both upper and lower motor neurons.
  • The SOD1 gene encodes for the enzyme superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), which plays a crucial role in protecting cells (Brain) from oxidative stress.

    • Mutations in the SOD1 gene are associated with familial cases of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

  • ALS is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord, leading to muscle weakness, atrophy, and eventually paralysis.

  • Bunina bodies are seen on brain biopsy of ALS patients.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the primary function of chaperones within the cellular environment?

choices.text: Facilitating the degradation of misfolded proteins
Promoting protein folding and preventing misfolding
Catalyzing enzymatic reactions by providing a scaffold

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Promoting protein folding and preventing misfolding

Explanation:

The primary role of Chaperones in the cellular environment is to facilitate proper protein folding and prevent misfolding.

  • Chaperones in the ER are responsible for properly folding newly synthesized proteins, and misfolded polypeptides are shuttled into the cytoplasm where they are ubiquitinated and targeted for proteolysis in proteasomes.
  • Chaperons works by the Ubiquitin Proteasome Pathway (UPP): Corrects the misfolding. Bit if the misfolded protein cannot be corrected then it is sent proteolysis or breakdown.

Disease

Misfolded protein

Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease

Prions

Cystic fibrosis

Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR)

questions.text: Which of the following pathways are responsible for the pathogenesis of ALS?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Ubiquitin-proteasome pathway

Explanation:

The ubiquitin-proteasome pathway plays a key role in the pathogenesis of ALS (Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis).

  • ALS is due to a mutation in the SOD-1 gene.
    • Mutant proteins start accumulating in brain.
  • The ubiquitin-proteasome pathway is primarily responsible for the degradation of misfolded proteins within the cell.
    • In this pathway, misfolded or damaged proteins are tagged with ubiquitin molecules, which target them for degradation by the proteasome, a large multi-subunit protein complex.
  • Dysfunction of the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway can lead to the accumulation of misfolded proteins and contribute to the pathogenesis of neurodegenerative diseases such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and Parkinson's disease.
  • In the SOD-1 gene defect, UPP is not working because of cellular defect.
